div.head: TO THE MOST HONOURABLE AND TRULY LEARNED The Phyitians, Chirurgions and Apothecaries Of the City of DUBLIN.
div.p:
VVHen I ee your INDEFATIGABLE Care in procuring men (that without which all the World is nothing) HEALTH, the PRIMARY caue, ole Foundation and Prop of Humane FELICITY; and how the experience of o many years manifets to all men, by the happy ucces of your Undertakings, and your great Charity to the Poor, that your private intentions do correpond admirably well with your external actions; and that all your indeavours are real and unfeigned: I am perwaded, that whatever can in any wie contribute to the promoting of your mot Noble and Generous Deign, can't but be acceptable to you. Wherefore having with the ame pasion, for the publick
Advantage, compoed the following mall Treatie, I take the liberty mot humbly to preent it You; that (as You are the bet JUDGES of the thing) o You may by Your Judicious and Impartial Cenure of it, inform the World of its worth; that no peron may be deceiv'd in it. For my intentions in publihing it, being to advance the common Good; if I thought it did contain any thing contrary to that DESIGN, I hou'd be the firt that wou'd indeavour its uppresion.

But, GENTLEMEN, beides the foregoing reaons, which I had of offering You this firt Eay of mine, I did it alo to acquit my elf in ome meaure of my Duty towards You; and to aure You further, that I am in all repects,

closer.signed: Your Mot Humble, Mot Obedient, And Mot Obliged Servant CHARLES ALLEN.

div.head: The PROEM.
div.p: KNowing that it is the duty of every man, and epecially of u h as live under a Civil Government, (where the general Interet always includes the particular) to contribute as much as he can (in his own tation) to the publick Good and alo of what Importance it is to all men to be informed of thoe Benefits which by my Art they may enjoy; I am reolved to et down here what I think mot convenient for every one to undertand concerning the preervation, and melioration of his own Teeth; A thing indeed of little eteem among mot people, but in truth, of inetimable value for its many and important conequences. However, in o doing, I hall acquit my elf of my duty towards God and Man: And provided my Indeavors prove but beneficial to others, (as certainly they will, if put in practice) it is all I deire, caring very little what opinion the Criticks of Words and artificial Logick may have of me.

Of what tility this ndertaking of mine may be to every body, will appear by the equel of this Dicoure; whereof the
cope is to prevent the los of Teeth; the ue of which is o neceary in the preparing of food, that the want of uch a help (if not upplied by trong diolvents) hinders a true concoction of the Aliments in the Stomach; whence do proceed Indigetions, and abundance of Crudities very noxious to the body of man; as being the eed of most of thoe innumerable Dieaes and Infirmities, whereby life is not only made troubleome to us, but alo coniderably horter than it would otherwie be, which is o cononant to truth, that vulgar obervation it elf has turned it into a common Proverb: For they ue to ay of one whoe Teeth are naturally thin, that he is hort-lv'd, whereof the reaon is, that uch perons do not chew their meat well. Moreover, the los of Teeth renders the pronounciation both troubleome to ones elf, and unintelligible to others. In a word, the corruption, and want of them, is as great a deformity, and of as much prejudice to one, as any thing whatoever can be.

div.head: SECTION I. Of the Nature of the TEETH.
div.p:
WHat men are wont to call Science, or the Cognition of any being, is by them commonly divided into two everal parts: one whereof is termed Theoretical, and the other Practical. The firt includes the reaons and caues of things, with the order and manner of their progres in coming to be what they are. The econd regards only their Properties and Effects, and what they are actually in themelves, without inquiring how they come to be o made, or thus qualify'd. As for example of thoe two branches of Humane Learning, (in repect to Phyical matters) when Philoophers go about to inpect the nature of the Loadtone, they earch into its Origine, tracing out the everal caues of its Formation, even to their ource or pring-head; from whence they draw arguments for the olution of all the Phenomena thereof; whereas Mariners conider it only as a certain Stone that draws Iron to it elf, having the power of communicating its properties to the aid Iron; and which, if not hindred (by its own gravity, or any other impediment) will always turn one of its ides towards the North, and another diametrically oppoite to the firt towards the South; which ufficeth them for the ue they make on't, in directing their coures through the Sea, without caring what may be the caue of o admirable
vertues in the Magnet. Either of which contituent parts of Knowledge being eparated from the other, cannot afford a full and atisfactory account of a thing: And therefore being about to treat of my Art, I hould by conequence begin with its Theory, and dicoure of the Elements, Principles, and firt Rudiments of the Teeth; which make the Subject thereof, unfolding the reaons of their contitution and frame, and how they come to have everal Roots, and to grow above the Gums; with what ever ele may be the caue of their pecifical being; and thence pas to the Practice. But ome Coniderations obliging me to defer treating of the former Part, or Theorick, till a better opportunity, I deign only to lay down in this Paper ome of the mot principal Points relating to the other; namely, the Practical part of my Profeion. In doing which, although it would be enough for us to peak of things, as in the tate wherein we find them: yet for the atisfaction of the Reader, and out of a real deire to erve him; we hall not detitute our Dicoure of uch Reaons as are neceary for the well undertanding of what we hall ay. So that although this Tractate will be imperfect, as wanting many things, yet what it hall contain, will be as ueful and advantageous as if it were accompanied with all the ret. However, according to the method we have precribed our elves here, we are to proceed next to the conideration of the Structure, and contitution or nature of the Tooth.

In Analying the Tooth, its ubtance is not found to
be uniform every where, but manifetly ditinguihable into two different orts of make: one of them being harder, whiter, and of a finer texture; and the other ofter, more obcure, and of a courer compoition. The firt makes up the head of the Tooth, or that part of it that tands out naked above the Gums and the other its tump, or that part on't which is hidden within the aid Gums. The expoed part of the Tooth conits alo of two different Parts: To wit, its tony Cover or Cae, and its inward ubtance the firt is as it were an hard Perioteum, that invets the head of the Tooth on all ides, lying on it much after the ame manner that Enamel does upon Gold, or any other thing. This natural Enamel which I call the glos of the Tooth, is of a far harder, whiter, more dene and lucid nature than the inward ubtance lying under it: which for its everal ues may properly be compared to the Cuticula, or Scarf-skin, for like unto this it is bloodles, and altogether detitute of ene, erving to cover and defend the extremities of the Veels, contained within the inward ubtance, from external injuries, and to render the Tooth more beautiful and trong. It has pores for the perpiration of the excrements of the Tooth, which pores are not always of the ame figure, nor magnitude, but vary almot in every body. The aid glos or tony ubtance is likewie very various in point of thicknes: from which differences, do arie the diverity of its colour in everal men.

The inward part of the head of the Tooth, though
inferior to its cover or glos in brightnes and olidity, yet its ubtance is nevertheles much more compact, and clearer than that of the tump: and contains two everal orts of pores, or mall channels, both of a conical figure, having their Baes in the concave uperficies of the Tooth, and their Apexes in the convex uperficies of the inward ubtance, immediately under its glay integument. Through ome of which channels the blood is carried by many and very mall Arterial Sprigs, from the middle of the Tooth to its extremity: and through the others the ame blood is ent back again from the aid extremity towards its middle, by ome capillary veins, as hall be aid hereafter.

As to the root or tump of the Tooth, it is the darket, mot oft, and porous portion of its whole ubtance; and yet is cloer and harder than any other bone of the body, having alo two orts of channels, but of different ituation from one another: for ome of them have their Baes (like thoe above decribed) towards the cavity of the Tooth, and contain the branches of the Artery, that carry the blood quite through the ubtance of the Tooth, to the Gums, as hall be explained in its place; but the others contrary to any of thoe already mentioned, have their Baes towards the external uperficies of the Tooth; the ue of which lat conduits, is to tranmit to the Gums the blood that is returned to the heart from the membrane that invets the cavity of the Tooth. This rooty part of the Tooth conits in the mall Teeth
of a ingle body, and in the big ones is divided into two, three, or four branches, called roots or fangs: along the middle of each of thee fangs, there is a little channel that goes up to the head of the Tooth, where they are united together, and make but a ingle cavity, whereinto are carried the veels of the Tooth, paing firt through the hollownes of the tumps. Every Tooth has its particular cell or ocket within the Mandible, ditinct from all the ret (by a thin production of the jaw-bone paing between the Teeth, from one ide of the aid bone to the other) wherein mot of its tump is comprehended, the ret being incompaed about with the Gums.

div.head: SECT. II. Of the Alteration of the Teeth, with their Remedies.
div.p:
FRom the conideration of the nature of the Teeth, let us now pas to that of the firt tep of their degenerating, or mutation. For the better undertanding of which, we hall take notice, that as our body is o made by nature, that it wats continually by the disipation of ome Particles, eparating themelves from its Mas, without intermision; (tranpiring for the mot part through the pores of the skin) and that if thee particles (which being divided from the whole, become Excrementitious) are kept too long within the body, (by reaon of the Opilation of the aid pores) it caues Fevors, and great diorders in our blood, and vital as well as animal Functions: So likewie from
the ubtance of the Teeth are emitted certain Effluviums through their pores, the tranpiration of which being hindred, (by the obtruction of thoe inviible paages) the Teeth become liable to all thoe infirmities hereafter to be mentioned.

The ubtance of the Tooth being rigid and inflexible, it cannot be Opilated by contraction, or atriction: as the skin uually is but only by the intruion of ome extraneous matter into its pores, or the incrutation of ome limy tuff upon its uperficies; which is done when we eat any thing of a glutinous nature, for then ome of its mot vicous parts do tick, and cleave about the Teeth; and by the mixture of ome tartarious particles coming from the Lungs, the heat of the mouth, and a certain petrifick juice ditilling into the mouth, out of the Salival Ducts, is turned into a tone-like ubtance, commonly called the cales or curf of the Teeth: thee cales grow thicker and thicker continually, and if let alone, will cover the Teeth all over, except jut at the top were they grind one againt another.

Having thus taken notice of the production of thoe cales, let us now conider of what ill conequences they may be to the Teeth. The firt whereof is the Opilation of their pores, from whence proceed all the ret: for by that the exit of thoe Excrementitious particles before mentitioned being hindred, it caues them to tagnate within the body of the Tooth, and there corrupting, do corrode it by degrees; beginning firt by the alteration of its colour from white to yellow,
and from yellow to black; and then follows the real decay of its ubtance, &c.

The aid humor is not only detructive to the Teeth, but extends alo its malignity to the Gums; ome of its particles being ubtil enough (after a due fermentation) to pas through the cales, and thence liding between the Gums and the Teeth, they eat clear away the ligaments that tye them together, dividing them one from another to the very jaw-bone: which is ufficiently proved by the excoriation and rawnes of the Gums, and their being o tender and looe from the Teeth where ever uch cales are found; and epecially if they be grown to a coniderable thicknes.

It happens ometimes that the uual paages of this corrupted humor being topt by the cales, (when they are hard, and cloe enough) is thereby repercued, and made to take its coure towards the middle of the Tooth, dicharging it elf therein between the Concave upericies of the Tooth, and the Tunicle inveting the ame; where it occaions very great pains, and at lat by its fretting, and corroive quality, gnaws and conumes quite away the aid membrane, as alo the veels of the Tooth; and then paing out of the aid Tooth, it diffues it elf through the Alveolus or ocket, where exerting its dangerous faculty, it detroys utterly whatever caues any connexion between the Teeth, the jaw-bone and the Gums, as the Perioteum, &c. After which the Teeth do conequently fall out for the mot part ound, and unaltered, except only in their colour, (which becomes yellowih) by reaon that the
aforeaid Excrementitious Humour being at firt diverted another way, did not tay long enough under the cales to occaion in them a greater detriment: All which incommodities to obviate, keep only your Teeth clean from curf, or any foulnes; and if they be already clean, you need but to preerve them as they are; but if not, get them to be made o by ome Artit in that Function; for otherwie if you employ any body that is unskilful in it, you may chance to find the Remedy wore than the Dieae; by reaon that not knowing the dangers attending uch an Operation, he may commit a great many and pernicious Errors, as the breaking of the Film that unites the Gums to the Teeth, the taking away of the glos of the Teeth, &c. Soon after which, the Tooth will loe its natural lutre, and become yellowih, ubject to ake, and at lat wholly perih away, the Gums being looe and broken, will likewie decay, and fall away from the Teeth, &c.

Your Teeth being once clean, you may preerve them with this compoition; Take Magitery of Pearls, Powder of Coral, and Dragons-Blood, of each equal quantity, and as much Red-Roe-water as will incorporate them together; and make the Compound of a mean conitence, between hard and oft. I have to that effect a very excellent Dentifrice, which being ued only once a week will keep the Teeth clean and white; and by the contant uing of it, fetch up their colour, if lot; (tho in a coniderable meaure) this is the ame that in my Bills (to keep my Maters term, tho improper,
as he well knows himelf,) I call an Opiat

div.head: SECT. III. Of the Corruption of the Teeth, with their Remedies Whereto is Annexed the Decription and e of the Polican.
div.p: HAving in the former Section conidered the Teeth, as at the beginning of their decay, in uch a condition as tho they uffer ome light change in their accidents, yet their ubtance, form and proportion remaining till the ame, is only called alteration; that is, in a tate wherein indeed they are invironed, and aaulted by their greatet enemies, but yet in a capacity of being recued and preerved from their harms. But now we hall conider them as overcome by all thoe threatning evils, and really corrupted; in which cae, all that can be done, is to prevent their total ruine.

And as there are ome not o far gone, but that they may till do good ervice, if timely helped, we are to ue our utmot indeavours to do it; which to effect, we hall in the firt place clear their outide from all foulnes, and then with a proper Intrument crape off whatever is rotten within, wahing them very well afterwards with ome convenient liquid, to cour and mooth away what the Intrument may leave behind: and then if the Tooth be o hollow that it may be topt, it mut be fill'd up with uch ingredients as are neither corroive, nor ill tated, and of a conitence firm enough to be ued in the ame manner
as the Teeth are, and to keep from wating for a coniderable time; but if the Tooth rots every way equally, o that there is no cavity left, wherein any thing can keep fat, it mut only be kept clean, taking care after every meal to pick out any meat that may get into it, and then wah it very well with fair water; for if you neglect o to do, the corruption of the rotten Tooth will fall upon the others, and o infect all the ret.

With thee precautions, I would advie every one to keep his Teeth as long as he can, although they were rotten to the very Gums, provided only they do not ake, by reaon that their tumps filling up their ockets, erve (like o many wedges) to keep the others treight and firm in their places; but if they are very bad, and withal ubject to ake, it is better to have them out, let they hould occaion an ill habit in the Gums, that might be hurtful to the ound ones.

The Drawing out of Teeth is practied by a great many, but perhaps undertood but of very few; and I am ure that there is a great deal more danger in the Drawing of a Tooth, (epecially out of the lower Jaw, than mot people are commonly aware of. It is an Operation that requires to be performed with great care and circumpection, and not o rahly as it is commonly done.

But as the greatet difficulty of this Buines lies in undertanding the make, and application of the Intruments that are imploy'd about the Drawing of Teeth; I hall (for the benefit of Practitioners, as well
as of thoe that will be their Patients) ubjoyn here, the decription and ue of the Polican; which is one of the bet of them.

div.head: The Decription and e of the Polican.
div.p: THe Contruction, and uual hape of the Polican, is a thing o well known by every body, that it wou'd be needles to init at all upon it. And therefore, without loing time in uch uperfluous Dicoures, we hall here take notice of ome other things appertaining to the aid Intrument, more material and ueful: as the due proportion that its parts ought to have, conidered in themelves, and in repect of each other.

In the firt place then, (uppoing that you know the tuff wherewithal it mut be made, which ought to be a tough teel, or teel and iron together) let the tree of the Polican be about four inches long, and o perforated, that the ditance betwixt the centre of the hole (wherein goes the pin upon which are fatned the two branches) and one of the extremities, be a line greater than the other. Let one of the two branches be two lines longer than the other; let alo each claw be three lines long. And finally, let the ditance between the bolter, or emicircle of the longet ide of the tree, be two lines. And you will have four ditances between the claws and the bolters, which is ufficient to draw all orts of Teeth. For with the firt, which is of two lines, you may draw the Inciores
With the econd, of three lines, you may draw the Ganini. With the third, of four lines, the Double and Treble Teeth. And with the fourth, of five lines, the Quadruple ones.

Your Polican being thus made, if you have a mind to ue it, you mut o apply the Claw to the inide of the Tooth you intend to pull out, that its branch may tand exactly upon the middle of the aid Tooth, gently leaning your Bolter upon the next to it, the better to take your meaures; and then draw the Tooth out. But take heed you do not draw obliquely, but in a direct line from the Tooth outwardly; for in drawing laterally, you might chance o to force the Tooth to be drawn, upon the next to it, that you wou'd draw them both together, or at leat looen very much the ound one, and put a far greater force upon the other in drawing it, than is neceary. Which wou'd occaion an infinitely greater pain to the Patient, than if you had done it rightly.

Thus much have I thought fit to tell you concerning the nature and ue of the Polican; which if you oberve punctually, you need never fear the Drawing well of any Tooth. As for the ret of the Intruments now in ue, with everal others of my own Invention, I hall give you the particular Decription, and ue of every one of them in the next Impreion of this Dicoure; if you think this worthy of your acceptance

div.head: SECT. IV. Of the Retauration of the Teeth.
div.p: WHen our decay'd Teeth are o far gone before we think of any Remedy for their preervation, that whatever we can do, proves but fruitles And that notwithtanding all our bet indeavours, they perih, and rot quite away; or that ome intolerable pain has made us to draw them; we are not yet to depair, and eteem our elves toothles for all the ret of our life: the los indeed is great, but not irreparable; there is till ome help for it, the natural want may be upplied artificially, and herein Art imitates Nature o naifly, that when the uccedaneous Teeth (if I may o peak) are well et in, they cannot be ditinguihed from the natural ones, (neither in colour, firmnes, nor proportion) but by them that know of it. Being thus exactly fitted to their place, they will keep the next to them, and by conequence all the ret of that Jaw abundantly firmer and tronger than they would otherwie be.

The Advantages that may be attributed to the artificial Teeth, are many; as that they keep the others fat, as we aid jut now, that they are of a great ornament, and help pronounciation extremely, &c. But all that is with a Provio, that they be well made, and according to the bet Art; for otherwie they might prove quite contrary.

Beides this Artificial way of repairing the los of
Teeth, there is another that may be called Natural; which is done by taking out the rotten Teeth or tumps, and putting in their places ome ound ones, drawn immediately after out of ome poor body's head: which thing (tho difficult) I know to be feaible enough, not only by my own reaon that tells me o, but by experience it elf, as (to ay no more at preent) may be intanced in the cae of a certain Lady, who thinking to have two Teeth growing one on the top of another, came one day to my Mater to have one of them Drawn: my Mater told her that they were not two ditinct Teeth, but only a double one; but the Lady being not atisfied with this, deired him to take out the Tooth he had told him of, let it be what it would. The Tooth being drawn out, and proving as my Mater had aid, it was quickly et again into the Jaw; and with the ue of ome convenient and proper Remedies, became in few weeks to be as firm again as any of the ret.

And yet although the event of this particular had not proved o properous as it did; its ill ucces would not detroy in me the poibility of uch a tranplanting, or Inoculation of Teeth: (if I may be permitted to ue uch terms) that was not the only motive I had to believe it; and I have not inerted the Story of it here as an Argument to prove invincibly what I ay, but only as a proper Example to render probable to others what I know to be true. However, I do not like that method of drawing Teeth out of ome folks heads, to put them into others, both for its being too
inhumane, and attended with too many difficulties; and then neither could this be called the retauration of Teeth, ince the reparation of one, is the ruine of another; it is only robbing of Peter to pay Paul. But if intead of humane Teeth, there is ue made of thoe of ome Brutes, as Dogs, Sheep, &c. In uch cae I do not only approve of it as lawful and facile, but do alo eteem it as very profitable and advantageous; only care is to be had, that the thing be undertaken, and carried on by one that at leat knows omething of Anatomy, and has a right ene of the thing to be done, being furnihed with whatever is neceary in an Operation of that nature.

And that (if my Opinion may be any wie erviceable in uch an Attempt) I may contribute omething towards the improvement of o ueful an Invention; I think one is, to proceed in it omewhat after this manner. Firt, I would chue an Animal whoe Teeth hould come nearet to thoe of the Patient; as a Dog, a Sheep, a Goat, or a Baboon, &c. and having tied his legs together, I would faten his head in ome convenient place, o that he might not tir in the leat, and by ome proper means keep his mouth open as long as I hould have occaion: that done, I would open the Gums round about the Tooth to be taken out of his head, not only to the very Jaw-bone, but as far between the aid Bone and the Tooth, as the finet Intrument could go, leaving a very little portion of the Gums about it; and then having ued the ame circumpection, in dividing the Patients Tooth from the
Gums, and the Jaw-bone, I would draw it forth, and put immediately in its place that of of the Brute; fatning it very well and treight between the other Teeth: and then with the ue of uitable Remedies, I do not quetion in the leat but that it would unite to the Gums and Jaw-bone, and in a little time become as fat as any of the others: which performance might properly be termed the natural Retauration, or Renovation of Humane Teeth.

div.head: SECT. V. Of the Tooth-ake, Looenes of the Teeth, and decay of the Gums; with their Remedies.
div.p:
THe Tooth-Ake is occaioned many and very different ways, but that I may render what I have to ay upon it, as perpicuous and intelligible as I can; I think it very convenient we hould take a pecial notice of the veels that come into the Tooth, and of their repective Functions. The firt and chiefet whereof is an Artery, whoe Office is to bring directly from the heart that hot and pirituous blood, out of which (although it is not the general Opinion) the Tooth is at firt made, (as well as the ret of the whole body) and ever after preerved and repaired by the upply of nourihment, and vital principles it affords continually: To this effect the whole Artery divides it elf into an infinity of mall branches, which being dieminated throughout the whole ubtance of the Tooth, ditribute to each part as much of their
blood as is neceary to make up the inceant los they are ubject to; and the ret is returned through innumerable hair-like veins into the great ones, and thence to the heart again, but in two different manners: for the uperfluous part of that portion of the blood, that is carried by the Capillary Arteries to that part of the Tooth tanding above the Gums, is ent back again through ome Capillary veins towards the middle of the Tooth; where uniting together, they make but a ingle channel; and this is it we commonly call the vein of the Tooth, which we hall here take for its econd veel. But the remainder of the blood, that goes to the relief of that part of the Tooth that is within the Gums, paing quite through the ubtance of the Tooth, is carried by the Capillary veins to the veins of the Gums, Checks, and Lips; and hence it is that whatever pain is at any time occaioned in any of thoe parts, (either by bruie, exceive heat, or cold, &c.) comes to be oon after communicated to the Teeth.

The Third and Lat Veel of the Teeth is a Nerve, one of the extremities whereof is expanded through the Membrane that invets the cavity of the Tooth, and that, that contains its Veels; and the other is rooted in the Brain, from whence it takes its Origine, and where the Animal Spirits being elaborated, are thence ent by the Nerves to all the parts of the body, to adminiter ene, and the caue of motion to them, &c. although in ome, (as the Teeth) the faculty of motion is not exercied.

From this conideration of the Veels of the Tooth, we may gather the following reaons of its Dolour; As firt, that if either through the too great quantity, or ebulition of the blood, the Artery is o dilated and woln, that it fills up the hole at the end of the tumps where it enters the Tooth, and conequently o comprees the vein going out the ame way, that the circulation of the Blood is thereby hindred; the continual flowing in of the blood will extremely puff up, and ditend the membrane that contains the veels, and conequently caue a great pain in the Tooth, which will lat till either the preternatural tate of the Blood be changed, or that the Arteriols which we have aid to pas quite through the rooty part of the Tooth be o tretched and widened, that by them the Blood may be dicharged into the Gums, Cheeks and Lips; where it will then caue a welling, greater or leer, according to the quantity of the uperfluous Blood.

And if at the beginning of this diorder, when the Vein is firt impeded in its Function, the motion of the Blood is o rapid, and its influx into the Tooth o impetuous, that before it can make its way through the mall Arterial Twigs into the Gums, it does extremely extend the coats of the Artery, the Intertices between their Fibres will thereby become wide enough to give paage to ome of the thinnet parts of the Blood; which gathering at the end of the root, between the outide of the Artery, and the common Coat inveting all the Veels, will there putrifie, and caue a great and very lating pain in the Tooth; during which,
if the Tooth be drawn, the aid gathering will appear at the end of its tump like a little Bladder.

You hall know this ort of Tooth-Ake by the high beating of your Pule, the fulnes of the Veins, and an often beating in the affected Tooth; with a continual, tho not very extreme pain. And then for the Cure of it, you mut firt bleed the Gums, and ometimes open a Vein in the Arm alo, and wah your mouth with Roe-water and Vinegar, of each equal quantities mixt together; putting a little Cotton dipt in Oyl of Box into the Tooth, if it be hollow.

Furthermore, if that portion of the Blood, which is diffued through the ubtance of the Brain for the production of the Animal Spirits, is o depraved, that all the ifting it receives, through the hidden meanders, and recees of the Brain cannot clear it from its impurities; and that notwithtanding all the contrivances of Nature it is depoited into the ventricles of the Brain, (tho under another form yet) till impregnated with its ill qualities: uch ort of Animal Spirits being compounded of Heterogeneous parts, if not timely dicharged of their malignant and offenive Corpucles, (through the uual Emunctories) will either by their fermentation in the Ventricles of the Brain, caue an Head-ake; or by the oppilation of its pores, caue a giddines; or ele paing out of the Brain into the Nerves, will by their irregular motion, and preternatural extention of the coats of the Nerves, and other Tunicles, breed a diturbance in all the parts they go to; but more particularly in the Teeth, in which they
always excite very great pains. For dicharging the peccant humour, between the membrane that invets the inide of the Tooth, and that that incloes its veels, it occaions a perpetual torment in them, till it be expelled from thence by tranpiration.

This econd kind of Tooth-ake will be known by a diturbance in the head, which precedes it mot commonly; a orenes in the joynts, and a certain drouines, and lingring pain all over the body, as if one were inclined to an Ague, with a harp and very exceive pain in the ditempered Tooth, which comes by fits, oon ceaing, and often beginning a-new. As for its Cure, it may be effected by Sternutation, the friction of the nape of the Neck with warm clothes, and the application of aperitive Remedies, to open the pores of the Tooth: and if it be hollow, you hall put in't a drop of Oyl of Camphire, whereinto has been infued ome Henbane-root. Thee are the two general caues of the Tooth-ake; all the ret proceeding from them, ome few excepted.

There is what I had a mind to ay at this preent concerning the Tooth-ake. But you mut note further, that as it is not enough for one that intends to travel a Countrey over, to undertand the Map of that Countrey; but he mut alo inquire often of the people he meets with as he goes on his journey, for the way to uch and uch a place: o although I have given you a true account of the Tooth-ake, and have delivered here the right method for the curing of it, yet that Dieae is for the mot part accompanied with
everal circumtances, that can't be learnt but from experience it elf. Thus ometimes the Gums will be livid, ometimes pale, and ometimes red, and inflamed. Sometimes the Tooth is looe, and rien above the others. And ometimes its root is dicovered, and bare of fleh. Sometimes its rotten, and otherwhile ound, as to its ubtance. In fine, ometimes the pain is accompanied with a great fluxion of Rhume, and ometimes with a drynes of the mouth, &c. Each of which concomitants requires a particular conideration, and peculiar Remedies: conidering always thee things, with reference to the age, contitution and habit of the Patient.

Again, it is but rarely, that a Tooth-ake is found imple, or uncompound: (as we have uppoed to be, thoe of which we have treated above) that is, occaioned by one caue only: but it proceeds mot commonly from everal; and epecially if the pain be inveterate, or of a long tanding. And then, the ymptoms of this complicated Dieae, are mixt in the ame proportion as their caues; which renders the Cure much more difficult, and ubject to more obervations. And therefore, if any one has a mind to render himelf perfect in thee things, he mut not only follow our method, that directs him to the true knowledge of them, but the dictates of his own enes alo; by which he will avoid all the obtacles he may meet with by the way. Notwithtanding all which, people being commonly unwilling to undergo all the trouble attending a methodical Cure, and withal apt to think, that one does them
no good at all, unles he gives them eae preently; I have been forced to abandon the Art in my practice, and to invent certain general Remedies; which nevertheles applying with circumpection, and as I think occaion requires, hardly ever fail of producing the intended effect: ometimes in an intant, but mot commonly within les than half an hour. True it is, that were it not for my former practice, and long habit in thoe things, I neither cou'd have, nor expect o good a ucces.

And yet I will not deny, but that the aid remedies happen ometimes to operate a great deal lower than ordinary. But that comes to pas by reaon of ome unexpected, or unoberv'd accidents: and I think it ought to uffice, that the Cure be at lat performed. Yet this does not atisfy every body. If the Remedy does not immediately Cure uch as are Impatient or incapable of reaoning, they trait condemn it as a thing ineffectual, and altogether void of any Virtue. Upon which, believing the Stories of ome impertinent (tho perhaps well affectioned) friend, they make ue of uch things, as commonly hinder the effect of the Remedy. And if it happens ometimes that notwithtanding thoe impediments, our remedy produces its effect; they never fail of attributing the Cure to their own indeavours.

However, I mut ingenuouly confes, that my Remedies do not take effect always. And that there are ome orts of Tooth-ake almot incurable, unles it be pulliatively; and that it elf, not without a great
deal of trouble, and a tedious while. The reaons of which, I hall take occaion to explain ome other time.

The looenes of the Teeth, comes mot commonly from the decay of the Gums, which are ubject to many infi • mities, proceeding for the mot part from thoe things that occaion the Tooth-ake, and putrefaction of the Teeth; for ometimes there will be uch an affluence of blood from the Teeth into the Gums, that their veins being not able to contain it, are thereupon broken; hedding the blood between the Gums and the Teeth: where gathering together, it corrupts, rotting away all the fleh from about the Teeth: otherwhiles the excrementitious humour, that exudates out of the Teeth, falling upon the Gums, eats them away by degrees, &c. But above all other things, the cales, and foulnes of the Teeth are very prejudicial to them. All which infirmities to avoid, you need but to keep your Teeth and Gums neat and clean from any foulnes whatoever; as has been already aid in the foregoing Sections: preventing any preternatural collection of Blood, or any other humours within the Gums. But if the michief is already done, that is, if your Teeth be really looe, and your Gums wated, you mut have recoure for their recovery to one well vered in thoe things. For to precribe you here any form of Remedies, would be to no purpoe, ince the ame thing cannot be equally good in all caes, and that without the perfect knowledge of the caue of the Dieae, and a right method in applying uitable Medicaments, (which commonly is undertood only by
Practitioners in thoe concerns) it is imposible ever to perform the Cure of any Ditemper.

Yet, that you may not think me remis in any thing belonging to my Profesion, that may concern your welfare; and by reaon that you may chance to find your elves in a place where there will be no Artit to help you; I will here communicate to you a general Remedy againt the decay of the Gums, and looenes of the Teeth; which I am ure, if you ue carefully, will often anwer your expectations: At leat it will be uch, that it hall always do you ome good, and never any harm. But I mut tell you before-hand, that if your body be Scorbutick, and full of ill humours, you mut firt be Blooded, and Purg'd, according to the directions of a good Phyitian: and then you may ue the aid Remedy as followeth.

Take of Matick, Myrrh, Pine-Apple, Dragons-blood, in drops, all reduced into Powder, of each equal quantity, red Coral prepared, flowers of Pomgranats, of each double the quantity of the other Ingredients; and teep them all in a proportionable quantity of Spring-water upon warm Embers, for the pace of a natural day; and then filtrate the Infuion through a woollen-cloth, and keep it cloe in ome convenient veel. And when you have a mind to ue it, you hall take two or three poonfuls on't a day, keeping it in your mouth a quarter of an hour every time: which you mut continue to do while neceity hall require it.

I might have told you at the beginning of this Section, where I poke of the veels of the Teeth, that
their Artery comes from the Carotids; the vein <> the Jugular, and the inew from the fifth pair of Nerves: but if you are skilled in Anatomy, you know it better than I, and if not, my telling of it to you would ignify nothing at all, unles I hould in the ame time, give you an accurate decription of all thoe veels; tracing them from their Origine, even to the very lat of their Diviions, and furthet extremities; which would be improper in this place.

div.head: SECT. VI. Of Childrens Teeth.
div.p: HAving hitherto poken of the Teeth in reference to adult perons, and uch as are pat childhood: we hall explain in this Section, as uccinctly, and withal as clearly as we can, what is neceary to be known touching their growth, and change in children; a thing of no mall conequence, ince the life of Infants is therein o often concern'd.

The Child being born, remains Toothles, till he is about five or ix Months old: at which time his two foremot Teeth in each Jaw begin to appear, without keeping any contant order of Precedence: ometimes thoe above coming out firt, and ometimes thoe below. After them follow all the ret uccesively in both Mandibles: o next to thee come the four other Inciores, the four Canin or Dog-Teeth, and the firt eight Molares, (which are properly the double Teeth) and then come the four bigget Teeth of all, which may be
called Quadruple Teeth, as being about three times bigger than the mall ones: and after that the eight lat Teeth do follow; which in repect to the Inciores may be termed treble Teeth. But thee treble ones uually vary very much in time of growth, for it is but rarely that they all come forth in the ame year, the four lat of them eldom coming out before the one or two and twentieth year of our age; for which reaon uch Teeth are called by ome, Teeth of Widom; becaue that by that time, we hould have a full ue of our rational Faculty, though God knows how often it proves to be true.

The eight Inciores, and the four Dog-Teeth come the firt year; the eight double Teeth the econd year; and the four Quadruples, with the four firt Treble ones, the third. During the time of their eruption, and epecially when the four Quadruple ones break forth out of their Sockets, children are ubject to Fevers, and great alterations, which weakens them extremely, and often puts an end to their days; which comes to pas mot commonly, for want of help to facilitate their iue out of the Gums.

And as I look upon the knowledge of Childrens Teeth, as a ubject properly belonging to my Profeion; o I think my elf oblig'd to amend, amplifie, and render it as conducive to the preervation of the life, and health of Children, and to the preventing of all thoe Infirmities wherewith they are afflicted, (upon the account of the firt coming, and hedding of their Teeth) as my weak indeavours can make it.
And therefore I will to that end deliver here in few words, what reaon and experience have taught me concerning the ame; Proceeding thus,

In the firt place, I would advie uch as may be concerned in this Affair, to take a pecial care in oberving when the Child's Teeth begin to trouble him: which (beides his frowardnes, and exceive crying) may be known by his alivation or drivelling (as Nures are wont to tile it,) and the inflammation and welling of his Gums; and as oon as you perceive it to be o, you are to wah his mouth now and then with the following mixture: Take even or eight as new Figs as you can get, and boyl them in a pint or more of Whey, till they grow very oft, and then queeze the Whey, and as much of the ubtance of the Figs as you can through a cloth; of which liquor take half a pint; of Honey of Roes, and Syrup of Violets, of each half an ounce; and three or four poonfuls of Plantain-water: mix all together, and keep it cloe in a Bottel. The bet way to ue it, is with a tick of Liquorih beaten at one end into mall threads like a Comb-bruh, or little Broom, with which, being dipt in ome of the aid Liquor, you hall wah and rub the Childs Gums, (epecially where they are tumified) at leat five or ix times a day, continuing o to do, till you perceive the Gums to grow white above the Tooth: (which is a ign of great pain in that part, and that the young Tooth will in a little time break through the Gums) and then take a Lancet, or a very harp Pen-knife, and divide the white place, cutting it
down to the head of the ubjacent Tooth, with two Inciions croing one another at the centre of the white pot, continuing to ue the mixture as is aforeaid, till the Tooth appears above the Gums; oberving to ue the ame method at the coming out of every Tooth, which you may know by the foregoing tokens.

Now the Teeth being all come out (except only uch as remain latent within the Jaw, till about the two and twentieth year of ones age) they keep firm and trong till the child is a matter of ix or even years old, and then mot of them grow looe, and a while after are cat clear out. The treble Teeth never change, the Quadruples very rarely, but the Inciores, the Dog-Teeth, and the double ones always do; ometimes whole, (and then the econd Teeth, or thoe that are to ucceed them, are a long time before they grow up again;) but mot commonly their head only comes off, the other part remaining till for the making up of the next Tooth; like unto the firt production of a Vegetable Seed, or tender Sprig of a young Plant; for as the upper part of this being withered in the Winter following, by the rigorous cold of that Seaon, drops off in the next Spring: (by reaon that its texture being yet looe, and les firm, the pores or ap carrying veels, are over much dilated by the great affluence of the nutritive juice, and o give admittance to ome indigeted and groer particles than is convenient for the nourihment of the Vegetable: which particles being irregular, and unactive, their motion is oon topt; when-as a great cold intervening, comprees a little
the young Plant round about, o that they are congeal'd, and become fixt in their Ducts, or leading pipes, whereby that part being deprived of its due nourihment, fades away, and dries up,) and is ucceeded by a new Sprout hooting out of the tump, or remaining part. So likewie the young Teeth coming into the cold air, when they are yet tender, and les olid: thoe of them that are more uceptible of alteration, and more expoed to the inclemency of the weather; (as mut be thoe before, which by reaon of their malnes and ituation, cannot but be more ubject to adventitious accidents,) are thereby chill'd and repreed, and their parts thrut near one another, and driven back towards their centre, from whence the ubtance of the Tooth becoming cloer, and the intervals between its parts narrower, and interrupted in everal places, by the irregular motion of ome of the minutet of thoe parts, (which by reaon of their untablenes, and fluxibility, being dipoed to advance and obey the action of external Agents more than the others, do move diorderly, and poil the tructure of the ret:) the mall Veins and Arteries therein dipered, will become o extremely compreed, that the bloud they contain (which in Children is mot commonly gros and impure, as is apparent by their tupidity, and filthy cabs; as well as by that Feverih dipoition they are always inclined to; which argues a great diparity between the parts of their bloud,) is thereby topt in its coure, and detained in them; where the grosnes of its parts, and their incumbring figures will
oon dipoe them to ret, and remain intangled and coagulated together.

If you chance to reflect upon what I ay, when I acribe the great agitation of Childrens Bloud, and its being quiet and fixt in their Teeth, to the ame caue, viz. its foulnes, and the incongruity of its parts; you will perhaps be as angry with me, as the Satyr was againt the Traveller of the Fables, for his blowing hot and cold with the ame breath. But if you conider it a little more attentively, you hall find that this, as well as the aid Apologue, may eaily be reconciled with Reaon.

Furthermore, the Bloud coming from the live part of the Tooth, to enter the other; and being hindred thereof by the narrownes of the paages, and the reitance of the condened bloud, is upon that necearily determined to imploy the force of its motion round about, againt the parts lying immediately between the dead portion of the Tooth, and that which is alive; the which it conequently looens by degrees, and at lat breaks them all aunder; eparating thus the live body of the Tooth quite from its dead head; and the pace left between them permitting the trunk to grow, it hoots a new head; which riing above the Gums, thruts out the old one, becoming a perfect Tooth in its room.

But if in the mean while, through the too great adherence of the dead part to the Gums, the other is depreed, or retarded from growing, and by conequence is detained under the former too long; ome
of the broken particles remaining between them will corrode, and eat holes in the new head of the Tooth, and o it comes out already perihed: which to prevent, the firt Teeth mut be drawn out as oon as they appear any thing looe.

Moreover, it happens ometimes, that the new head of the Tooth is nourihed, and increaes o fat, that being obtructed by the too great connexion of the old one, to the adjacent parts, from advancing in its right coure; it turns aide, and makes its way through either the inide, or outide of the Gums; and o it grows biaing, and out of rank. This defect is remedied by drawing out the uperfluous Tooth, and the ue of ome convenient means to bring the new Tooth into its place; which is very eay to do, if undertaken at firt, but otherwie a great deal more difficult; and epecially if the two next Teeth are approached o near one another, that it cannot be contained between them, without being leened, or the others put further off from each other.
Note, That in drawing out the old, or ucking Tooth, a great care is to be taken not to hurt the new one, lying under it.

div.head: SECT. VII. Of the Acceleration of the Teeth.
div.p:
THe five firt of the foregoing Sections have been imploy'd about mens Teeth, and the ixth about thoe of Children: but this eventh and lat Section
of our Dicoure hall repect both men and children; for it will not only teach how to haten the growth of Childrens econd Teeth, when it happens to be delay'd, or retarded too long; but alo how to Accelerate the coming out of thoe in Men, that are called Teeth of Widom. Which lat, without the help of Art, hardly ever appear before almot half of our life is already pat away; And when the time of our growth is over: during which, we have the greatet occaion for them. But becaue the bare aying or aerting of any thing without proofs, or ome reaons to render it probable, has no force to perwade any man of its truth, nor to make him enible of what utility it is of; We will elucidate the matter in hand, by an example drown from the motion of Seeds own in the Earth. Now the quick or low germinating of Seeds after they have been own, depends upon their being buried hallow, or deep in the ground; the lightomnes or heavines of the Earth, and its good or ill manuring, and the proportion of humidity that dilutes it, as well as the heat or coldnes of the eaon: the everal proportions of either of which accidents, alter and vary the progres of the Seed, according to their prevalency in repect of each other.

For in a well prepar'd Soil, being cherihed by the warmth of the Sun, and duly diluted with water, the Seed will budd a great deal ooner; the lightome Earth eaily yielding to the expanion of the Semen, when it imbibes that Succus Nutritious, which Trancolating through the coats of the Seed, and impregnating its
Parenchyma, caues by its fermentation therein, a gentle hake, and a vital motion in the Radicle, and Plume; (as the Learned Doctor Grer •
calls the Seminal Root, and Trunck of a Plant in Embryo) whereby they are impowred to Extricate themelves out of their Integuments, and Parenchyma; and begin to vegetate, and grow like a Plant.

But the Seed being buried deep in a cold, cloggy earth; will, by the tubborn Coheion, and lumpihnes of the aid earth, be kept from dilating it elf, and conequently from receiving thoe particles that are altogether neceary for its vivifying, and augmentation. From whence it follows, that its growth (if not helped by Art) will be check'd, and obtructed till the heat of the Sun has opened the ground, and et its particles in uch motion as they ought to be, to enter the Seed, and protrude the earth upwards.

So likewie Childrens Gums, being yet tender, hallow, and looe, and withal prepar'd, as we have taught heretofore in its place, their firt Teeth come out, and grow very eaily; as alo do their econd, if in hedding of the firt, their heads only come off; for the others do grow up o oon, that the Gums have hardly any time to cloe up again. But if the ucking-Teeth do hed root and all, the matter out of which the next (which I call Novel-Teeth) are to be made, will not only be a coniderable time in dipoing it elf into the requiite form, but when the firt lineaments are drawn, and Nature has accomplihed her firt work, the Gums will be re-united together, and
grown o hard by that time, that their reitance will oppoe it elf to the growth of thee Teeth, till a tronger nourihment produces more and hotter Bloud, and a greater quantity of Animal Spirits; by which the Gums being made hotter, and more pungy, and the nutritive juice increaed, the iue of the aid Teeth will then be facilitated, and their growth perfected.

To the conideration of thee Novel-Teeth, may partly be referred that of the lat treble ones, or dentes apientiae. It's true, thee are tay'd a great deal longer under the Gums than the others; but alo they have more caues that impede their growth. For, beides that, the Gums are more inewy, and membranous about them than any where ele, and therefore much more difficult to penetrate: That part of the Jaw-bone that contains them, is likewie much thicker, and tronger than any other; and conequently, harder to be divided by the included Teeth; which being incapable of making their way through it, are forced to tay therein till uch time that Nature having perfected our growth, the bloud becomes hotter, tronger, and its energy more powerful by the firmnes of the Heart, (which is the Sun of our Microcom, or littleworld) and other principal parts, and increae of thoe particles that were wont to be imployed in making up, and augmenting the body; mot of which remain then in the mas of the Bloud: whereby the aid bloud, being able to urmount the reitance of the Jaw and Gums, forces the aid Teeth to come out of their cells, and grow up.

To the efficacy of this new trength of the Bloud upon the arrival of Nature to its highet Period, may be attributed the caues of thoe alterations that uually happen in mens bodies about that time: many looking pale, and being troubled with divers infirmities till then, of which they are afterwards delivered. But leaving off Digreions, let us return to our Subject.

We have already oberved, that the Novel-Teeth in Children, and Dentes Supientiae in Men, cou'd not arrive to their perfection, nor therefore become erviceable to us without a long time, and a great Effort of Nature. It remains now, that (puruant to our deign, as we have declar'd it at the beginning of this Section) we indeavor to find out ome means, whereby we may remedy thoe defects; in facilitating Nature's work, and rendring thoe tardy Teeth abovementioned, erviceable to us as oon as we can. And as I find none more proper and expeditious, than the Rarifaction, and Dilatation of the Gums, o that they may loe their greatet tubbornnes, and become more yielding to the Teeth: I conclude that all the difficulty lies in knowing how uch an effect can be produced: which (after a due conideration) I think may be performed after this manner.

In the firt place, there is need of an Intrument made of Gold, or Silver, about a foot long, as big as a Tobacco-pipe, and like a Syringe; being o bored, that a perfectly Cilindrical embolus, or ucker, may fill exactly nine inches of its Cavity; the ret being made a good
deal maller, and bow'd like the Blowing-pipe of Watch-makers; which ought to end into an head reembling the cup of an Acorn; and o contriv'd, that it may imbrace the Gums exactly. Your Intrument being ready, if you have a mind to perform the Operation, you mut in the next place (concerning the Dentes Sapientiae) tie all the Teeth together, (which may be done without any trouble) o that the two foremot of them may draw the lat of all towards the fore-part of the mouth. By this the included Teeth will be freed from being compreed between the others, and the extremity of the Jaw-bone. And then the Gums being prepar'd by Emollients, and relaxing things, apply the end of your Syringe cloe upon the Gums, under which the imperfect Tooth lies; and then draw the Embolus, and the top of the Gums will follow, and rie within the little Acorn-cup-like end of the Pipe, as the fleh uually doth under Cupping-Glases. Keep it a while o, and then take away the Syringe, and carifie that part of the Gums that was drawn within the Pipe, in everal places; reiterating the ame Operation twice a day, for about a fortnight, omitting only the Scarification, which is to be ued the firt time only. By this means it appears probable to me, that the Gums yielding, the force of the Blood will compel the fibres or minute parts of the imperfect Tooth, to advance according to their natural order, and ituation; and o caue the aid Tooth to grow.

As to the Novel-Teeth, you hall follow the ame method, and ue the ame means in facilitating their
coming out, that you have done to the others; omitting only the tying of the Teeth, which would be uperfluous here.

Note, that every thing is not capable of the ame perfection, and that as there is no rule without ome exception; o when I have aerted uch and uch things to be improvable to uch a degree, it is to be undertood for the mot part, and in general; not denying but that it may happen otherwie in ome particular caes: but I hall always deal candidly with every body, never undertaking any thing but what I hall be able to do according to agreement. And if any one will be pleaed to come to my Chamber, he may have my Advice (concerning any thing that belongs to my Profeion) gratis at any time.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT TO THE READERS.
div.p: ALthough I have offered nothing in this Paper, but what is according to my own Experience, and the bet of my knowledge; yet I will not ay but that I have been deficient in many things, and have committed a great many Errors in the management of my Subject; but if you conider that I am the firt (as far as I know) that ever wrote any thing of this nature; and withal, what is to be expected from one in my Circumtances, I hope you will be the more ready to excue my faults. However, if what I have done be acceptable to you, I intend in a econd Impreion of this mall Treatie, to Correct, Illutrate, and augment it, to its full proportion. In the mean while I would advie you, to make ue of what is here preented you, by

div.head: A Phyical Dicoure WHEREIN The Reaons of the Beating of the PULSE, or Pulation of the Arteries; Together with thoe of the Circulation of the Bloud, are Mechanically Explain'd: Which was never done before.
div.p: THe Beating of the Pule being one of thoe Phenomena, that deerve mans conideration the bet, it has excited the mot Learned in all Ages to earch out what might be the caue of it.
The bet Phyitians and greatet Philoophers of former times, being ignorant of the Circulation of the Bloud, did acribe it to their occult qualities, and unknown powers.

Galen, an Eminent Phyitian, earching the natural caue of the Beating of the Pule, thought upon the making of that famous Experiment of his; by which, having put a Quill into an Artery, and tied the Artery upon it, he found that the aid Artery ceaed from beating betwixt the ligature and the extremity, tho it continued till beating betwixt the ame ligature and the heart: And then eeing alo, that the Artery
being untied from about the Quill, the Pule would immediately pas beyond the place where the ligature had been made, and beat all along the Artery; altho the capacity of the Quill remained till the ame, he concluded, that the Pule was caued by a Puliick faculty reiding in the coats of the Artery.

Gaendus, a Modern and mot Learned Philoopher, attributed the aid effect, to the Pulifick Faculty of the heart; which, in his opinion, communicates it elf to the Arteries. Both which opinions (altho propos'd by extraordinary men, yet) are o inconiderable, that they need no refutation.

The mot Learned and mot Profound Carteius was of opinion, that the Beating of the Pule proceeded from the motion of the Bloud, which coming out of the let Ventricle of the Heart into the Aorta, in a tumultuous manner, extends it elf forcibly, and thereby drives all the mas of the Bloud, from the heart to the heart again, according to the Circulation of the Bloud. After which this great Man (who would always give natural and intelligible reaons for every thing, as he has done for mot;) coming (at the intigation of a Phyitian of Louvaine) to examine Galen's Experiment, he attributed the ceation of the Pule, that happens below the ligature, to the narrownes of the paage of the Bloud through the Quill; which Bloud, according to the principles of the Philotopher, coming out of the aid Quill into a wider pace, cannot communicate its action to the ides of the Artery, but is dipoed to imploy the force of its motion forwards, according to the length of the Artery.

But the aid Phyitian alledging againt this, that if one takes an Artery without Quill, or any Inciion, and ties its ides o cloe together, that there be left a far maller paage for the Bloud in that place, than in the Quill; the Artery will nevertheles continue till to Beat on both ides of the ligature, as it did before: (the contrary of which wou'd necearily follow if it were o, that the traitnes of the paage of the Bloud did occaion the los of the Pule) Carteius was here forced to recede omewhat from his former Sentiment, and to confes, that the motion of the Arteries depends partly upon the free continuation of their coats; which totally overthrows his opinion. For, let the power of the aid continuation be what it will; uppoing, as the Philoopher did, that its action may be topt by the compreion of the ides of the Artery: It is certain, that altho the Quill in the Artery were of equal, or, if you will, greater capacity than the Artery; yet if the aid Artery were tied upon it, the Pule would, notwithtanding all that, ceae below the ligature. But Carteius aid, that uch a Quill as that we were peaking of jut now, being in an Artery either tied, or untied; wou'd never hinder any part of the Artery from Beating: And therefore, &c.
Doctor Lower ays, after many Diquiitions on this Subject, that the knowledge of thoe things was left to God alone.

Doctor Willis acribes the Beating of the Pule to the contraction of the circular Fibres of the mucular coat of the Artery: But it is aburd to think o; for its impoible
to imagine that thoe Fibres cou'd contract themelves of their own accord; neither does the Doctor give any reaon for what he ays. Beides, he's inconitent with himelf, when he acribes the ame motions to the circular Fibres of the mucular coat of the veins; which are notwithtanding wholly detitute of any Pulation, &c.

All which conidering, and how thee and other great men had (through the difficulty of the thing, and not out of any inufficiency in them) fallen into o gros and o erroneous opinions concerning the Point in Quetion; I concluded, that it was as good as imposible ever to olve the difficulty. Yet, recollecting my elf, and eeing that the aid Effect mut have a caue, whatever it be, which probably cannot reide any where ele, but either in the Heart, Bloud, or coats of the Artery; or finally, in them all together; I made a reolution to examine carefully each one of thee things eparately, as posibly containing alone the caue ought after; and then all together, as being posibly Coadjutors in the production of the known Effect. And after as exact an Inquiry into the matter as I am capable of, my Reaons (which wou'd be too tedious to tell you now) perwade me, that all the Mytery conits in the three following things.

The Firt is, the Structure of the Artery; which is made up of four Coats. (We hall examine in another place how they are generated at firt) The firt of them, which contains the Bloud immediately, eems to be nervous, and made of trait Fibres; which take
their Origine from the heart; or rather are a continuation of thoe that immediately invet the cavity of the heart. As oon as they are arriv'd at the orifice of the heart, they rank themelves by one another; forming a certain Cartilagineous Ring; from the circumference of which, they run almot parallel along the Artery; but yet with uch an inclination towards one another, that going from the heart to the extreme parts, they form a kind of Cone; (for that we may render our Dicoure more intelligible; we hall conider here one of the trunks of the great Artery, (uppoe the acending one,) as a continued right Conical Pipe, abtracting from all its diviions and branches; to every one of which may eaily be apply'd, what we are going to ay of one of them,) a little below the Apex of which, thoe Fibres unite themelves together; and do compoe a little tendinous ring, called Anatomois: to which is affix'd the extremity of the vena cava: which vein we hall uppoe here to be a ingle conical channel, or pipe, dipoed, as we have taken the Artery to be. Within this Anatomois there is a little Valve o dipos'd, that it permits the bloud to pas from the Artery into the vein, but hinders it from returning back again from the vein into the Artery. Between every one of thoe nervous Fibres, there is a thin membrane that joyns them together; (as the skin in a Gooe'sfoot ties its toes to one another,) which permits the aid Fibres to open, and go further from one another, when the Artery is dilated: And which do continually increae in breath, as they go from the Anatomois to
the bais of the Artery: o that they become o conpicuous near the heart, that Doctor Willis took them for ome large flehy Fibres; to which he asign'd the faculty of hortning the Artery, in order to promote the circulation of the Bloud. The econd coat is the Mucular, and the third the Glandulous: but the conideration of thee middle coats, being not neceary to our preent purpoe, we hall peak of them another time. As to the fourth, or outmot Coat, it is that which we have mot need to take notice of here; as being the principal Intrument of the Sytole and Diatole of the Artery. This Coat is made up of two orders, or ranks of piral Fibres; which proceed from the oblique Fibres of the heart; from whence they go twiting and winding themelves about the body of the Artery, as Ivy does about Trees; ome running upon it from the left to the right, and the others from the right to the left; interecting thus one another obliquely, as they go from the heart to the anatomois; whereby they form a ort of Net, or Sieve-like-woof upon the outide of the Artery. At their coming out of the heart, they are knitted together by a cartilagineous ubtance, that incompaes the root of the Artery round about, as an iron-ring does the end of a handle: from the circumference of which cartilagineous Ring, they run Helix-wie upon the uperficies of the artery: at the extremity of which, being arriv'd, they inert themelves into the tendinous mall ring, or anatomois. Thee piral Fibres are tied o looely on the body of the artery, and o lightly between themelves, at the places
where they interect one another, that they may run very eaily to and fro upon the artery.

The econd thing conducive to the production of thoe tated turns of Sytole's and Diatole's of the artery, is, that the bloud contains a certain ubtil matter, or vital pirit, which can move it elf, and pas between its parts very eaily. And in fine, that the bloud coming out of the heart (where it acquires an extreme agitation) into the arteria magna, expands it elf with great violence, and trongly dilates that part of the aid artery that lies contiguous to the heart, (forcing in the ame time the bloud to advance from the heart towards the extremity,) whereby the piral Fibres being necearily drawn towards the dilating place, do compres the artery round about all along, & o queeze the ubtil matter, from between the parts of the compreed bloud, into that which is not; forcing it thus to pas from the extremity towards the heart, which makes the ebbing or ytole of the artery. And then the piral Fibres having been extended violently, and on a udden, upon the dilatation of the artery, do (by the Elatick faculty of ome of their parts) come back again, and retitute themelves into their former ituation, and tate; forcing thereby the ubtil matter to fly through the bloud, from the dilated place of the great Artery, towards the extremity of the capillary ones, &c. which makes the flowing or Diatole of the Artery.

div.head: THE EXPLICATION.
div.p: WE have already uppoed the Artery to be of a right Conical figure; let us further, for greater evidence, imagine it to be mentally divided into four parts of equal capacity: o that as much as the firt hall exceed the econd in bredth, the econd will exceed the firt in length, &c. Let beides, the places of the uppos'd diviions be marked with everal letters, as A, B, C, and let A, denote the firt diviion; (proceeding from the heart to the extremity;) B, the econd; and C, the third: let us alo mark the Bais of the Cylindrical artery, which is inerted into the bais of the heart, by X; and its capillary end inerted into the circumference of the annular anatomois, by Y.

And now, uppoe that a certain portion of bloud, as a dram for example, paes out of the heart into the aorta, where it wells, and dilates it elf very coniderably, (by reaon of a very intene degree of heat, it acquires in the ventricles of the heart; and of its being mixed therein with a certain leaven, or fermentative juice, (it being the reidue of that portion of bloud, that had pat immediately before through the heart,) which necearily caues a great commotion and trife amongt its parts;) it mut follow according to true Philoophy, that the aid portion of bloud coming out of the heart, does in the ame time thrut the bloud already in the artery, forwards, and dilates that part of the artery that lies contiguous to the heart.
It thruts the bloud, I ay, towards the extremity; becaue that it mut occupy a pace in the artery equal to its natural bulk, neither greater nor maller; by reaon that a like quantity of the bloud to that, that comes out of the heart into the artery, is poured out of the vein into the heart; o that there is only room left in the vein to admit jut as much bloud, as comes out of the heart at each Diatole. And if we uppoe the pace X A, to contain a dram of bloud, (whether more, or les, makes no matter here) as we have alo uppoed, that the ame quantity comes out of the heart at every Diatole, (or Sytole, as ome would have it) it is an invincible truth, that this bloud coming out of the heart, mut exactly occupy the pace X A; and that therefore, it thruts in the ame time, the bloud that occupied it before, into the pace A B; that in A B, into the pace B C; that in the pace B C, into the pace C Y; and that in C Y, into the capillary end of the vein, &c. And altho (according to our Hypotheis) the paage from the artery into the vein be much maller, than that of the heart into the artery; yet if the motion of the bloud through the anatomois, is to the motion of the bloud at the orifice of the heart, as the orifice of the heart is to the anatomois; that is, as X is to Y, (as it may eaily be o, altho it is naturally otherwie: the ret of the anatomoes, from which we have abtracted here, being together at leat as capacious, as the orifice of the heart,) it is plain, that a dram of bloud will as oon pas from the artery into the vein, as another hall from the heart into the artery.

And as the bloud coming out of the heart into the great artery, cannot posibly occupy a greater pace, than uch as is adequate to its volume in a condened tate; and that nevertheles it dilates it elf, it mut necearily extend and dilate X A, the part of the artery that contains it, as much beyond its natural tone, or reach, as the rarefaction of the bloud increaes its volume; which cannot come to pas, but thee two things mut necearily follow. Firt, that when the bloud dilates it elf, it leaves ome intervals between its parts; which intervals (becaue there is no vacuum in nature) mut in the ame time be filled up with ome other fluid matter: (which ought to be thinner than the bloud; for otherwie it cou'd not pas between its parts.) And as this ubtil matter can't come from the heart, becaue that then it's empty; and that beides its orifice is hut cloe by its three valves; it can neither come through the coats of the artery, by reaon of their thicknes, and cloe texture; neither is there any uch matter about them. It remains then only, that it mut come from the bloud contained in the artery.

Secondly, that the piral Fibres mut be drawn towards the dilated place, and the ret of the artery made as much narrower than ordinary, as X A, becomes wider than it ues to be. Whereby the artery being compreed round about, the vital pirit is queezed from between the compreed parts of the bloud, and forced to advance towards the dilated place; in uch manner, that as much of the pirit, as is neceary to fill
up the paces left between the parts of the dilated bloud, is ent thither from between the parts of that, which is compreed; the remnant of the pirit being equally ditributed through the ret of the artery; o that if every one of the four parts, or diviions of the artery, contains a certain quantity of vital pirit, ditinguihed into three parts, and that three of thoe parts, do pas from A B, into X A, two of them will in the ame intant pas from B C, into A B; and one from C Y, into B C; in which action conits the ebbing, or ytole of the artery. And as a rope, (or more enibly, a gut-tring) which is fixed to any place, being pulled with a jerk, will draw back again him that drew it at firt; o likewie the piral Fibres being extended violently, and on a udden, upon the dilatation of the artery, do come back again intantaneouly, (by reaon that ome of the parts of each Fibre, being trongly thruted towards its middle, and omewhat bent from its circumference towards its centre, do preently pring back again, extending themelves according to the bredth of the Fibre; whereby the aid Fibre is necearily as much hortned, as it had been tretch'd before) and retitute themelves into their former ituation & tone; (which they are facilitated to do by the extenuation of that extraordinary agitation of the bloud; which it communicates in an intant to the yielding ides of the artery) forcing thereby three parts of the vital pirit, or ubtil matter, to repas from X A, to A B; and the two parts, that were already in A B, to pas into B C; from whence another will pas into C Y, &c.
which makes the flowing, or Diatole of the artery.

I foreee an Objection, that ome may make againt what we have aid, that that portion of the bloud, that comes out of the heart in its Diatole, is dilated, and yet occupies no more of the artery, than if it were condened; only that part of the artery which contains it, is a little more extended than the ret: for, they will ay, this uppoes, that both the artery and the vein are always full of bloud; being certain, that if the bloud, in coming out of the heart into the great artery, did find there any empty pace, where it might expand it elf freely, it would tart forwards into it, and then it wou'd not dilate the artery, nor by conequence draw the piral Fibres; and therefore there wou'd neither be Sytole nor Diatole in the artery: But it is mot certain, they will continue, that men have ometimes more, and ometimes les bloud in their bodies: and that if a man has, for example, fifteen ounces of bloud drawn, it will follow; that there being a vacuity in the Sanguiducts, till the ame quantity of bloud be regenerated a-new, the Beating of the Pule mut alo ceae till then; which being contradicted by daily experience, they will conclude, that the motion of the piral Fibres, with whatever ele we have taught concerning the Beating of the Pule, is altogether chimerical. To which I anwer in few words, that for the Beating of the Pule, and Circulation of the Bloud, it matters not at all, whether or no, the artery and vein be quite full of bloud; ince that as the bloud decreaes in them, the mucles of the limbs, and other adjacent
parts, do proportionably compres them round about; o that their internal uperficies touches the bloud continually every way; which has the ame effect, as if the artery and vein were exactly full of bloud: for the bloud coming out of the heart, and finding as much difficulty in lifting up the adjacent parts, as to drive on the bloud of the artery and vein, when they are full on't; it's forced to keep the ame order and method in that cae, as it does in this, concerning its dilatation and place in the artery.

Now, thee being the true and genuine reaons of the Diatole, and Sytole of the arteries, it's very eay thereby to explain all the Phenomena relating to Galen's experiment. For the Quill being put into the artery, and left there without being tied, the artery will nevertheles beat till above and below the Quill, as it did before; becaue that the piral Fibres can till play to and fro from one end of the artery to the other, without impediment. But if you bind the ides of the artery upon the Quill, the motion of the ame piral Fibres will be intercopted by the ligature; o that it mut necearily follow, (by the foregoing reaons,) that the artery being not alternatively compreed, and dilated betwixt the aid ligature and the extremity, the Pule mut alo ceae in that part of the aid artery, &c.

Many things may eaily be explained by this Doctrine, tho impoible to be interpreted any otherwie; which therefore become as many proofs of its verity: as namely, the difference which is between the arterial
and venal bloud. For (having demontrated above, that when the bloud advances in the great artery from the heart towards the anatomois, and from thence into the vein, the vital pirit goes in the very ame time from the anatomois towards the heart; whereby the aid pirit is necearily kept within the artery;) it is certain, that this diparity proceeds from the want of pirit in the venal to keep its parts in agitation; which abounding in the arterial, keeps it in a continual effervency, &c. I cou'd add many other things to authorize what we have aid concerning the Beating of the Pule, and Circulation of the Bloud: but I hope this will uffice to rational men, and uch as are of a Mechanical Genius. As for thoe that attribute all things to final caues, and have recoure upon every occaion, to the deigns and intentions of Nature; (as when they ay, that the Eye-brows are made to hinder the Sweat from falling into the eyes, &c.) if, notwithtanding all that we can do, they remain till inenible to our reaons, it matters not much; and, in my opinion, uch perons had a great deal better tudy Atrology; or, if they are big with devotion, go and comment upon Job, or Paraphrae ome Palms, than meddle with Phyical matters.
